extendedIngredients.name: chile powder
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1/4 teaspoon red chile powder, or to taste

extendedIngredients.name: eggs
extendedIngredients.originalString: 4 large eggs or extra-large eggs, preferably free-range

extendedIngredients.name: sesame oil
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1/3 cup peanut oil or unroasted sesame oil

recipes.title: Naomi Duguid's Golden Egg Curry

winePairing.pairingText: Asian works really well with Riesling, Gewurztraminer, and Chenin Blanc. The best wine for Asian food depends on the cuisine and dish - of course - but these acidic whites pair with a number of traditional meals, spicy or not. You could try Pacific Rim Riesling. Reviewers quite like it with a 4.2 out of 5 star rating and a price of about 12 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Pacific Rim Riesling
productMatches.description: Portraying bright crispness, subtle sweetness and aromas of jasmine, pear and apple, Pacific Rim Riesling exemplifies the harmony of Riesling. The sweetness plays wonderfully with fiery fare (from Thai to Mexican), while the natural acidity stands up to richer foods (from French to German).

recipes.instructions: Procedures                                                                              1                                                                            Place the eggs in a saucepan, add cold water to cover, bring to a boil, and cook at a medium boil for 8 minutes. Drain the eggs and cool in cold water. When the eggs are cool enough to handle peel them.                                                                                                                            2                                                                            Heat the oil in a wide heavy skillet over medium-high heat. Add the tumeric and stir to dissolve it. When the oil is hot enough to sizzle when a drop of water is dropped into it, add the peeled eggs and fry until golden and a little blistered all over: cook on each side in turn, then try to balance the eggs on their ends to cook the tips. Frying the egg is a fun little task, quickly done, and it makes them very attractive. With a slotted spoon, lift the eggs out of the hot oil and onto a plate. Cut them lengthwise in half and set aside.                                                                                                                             3                                                                            Pour off all but 2 to 3 tablespoons of the oil (the oil can be used again for stir-frying). Heat the oil remaining in the pan over medium heat, add the shallots and garlic, and fry briefly, until translucent.  Add the chile powder and tomatoes and, stirring frequently to prevent sticking, cook at a strong simmer until the tomatoes have broken down into a softened mass, about 10 minutes.                                                                                                                            4                                                                            Stir in the fish sauce and salt, then taste and adjust the seasoning if you wish. Raise the heat to medium-high, add the chile strips, and stir. Place the eggs cut side down in the sauce and cook until the oil sizzles, about 3 minutes. Serve hot or at room temperature.

steps.step: Place the eggs in a saucepan, add cold water to cover, bring to a boil, and cook at a medium boil for 8 minutes.
Drain the eggs and cool in cold water. When the eggs are cool enough to handle peel them.
Heat the oil in a wide heavy skillet over medium-high heat.

Add the tumeric and stir to dissolve it. When the oil is hot enough to sizzle when a drop of water is dropped into it, add the peeled eggs and fry until golden and a little blistered all over: cook on each side in turn, then try to balance the eggs on their ends to cook the tips. Frying the egg is a fun little task, quickly done, and it makes them very attractive. With a slotted spoon, lift the eggs out of the hot oil and onto a plate.
Cut them lengthwise in half and set aside.
Pour off all but 2 to 3 tablespoons of the oil (the oil can be used again for stir-frying).
Heat the oil remaining in the pan over medium heat, add the shallots and garlic, and fry briefly, until translucent.
Add the chile powder and tomatoes and, stirring frequently to prevent sticking, cook at a strong simmer until the tomatoes have broken down into a softened mass, about 10 minutes.
Stir in the fish sauce and salt, then taste and adjust the seasoning if you wish. Raise the heat to medium-high, add the chile strips, and stir.
Place the eggs cut side down in the sauce and cook until the oil sizzles, about 3 minutes.
Serve hot or at room temperature.
